  • Dash cam
  • Upgraded stereo to take advantage of Apple Car play
  • New backup cam (old one was not working correctly)
  • New lift gate switch because the Florida sun literally melted the old one.

* Dash cam
* Upgraded stereo to take advantage of Apple Car play
* New backup cam (old one was not working correctly)
* New lift gate switch because the Florida sun literally melted the old one.

items.content_html:
One day when I actually have the time and resources (likely never, but one can still dream), I’m going to have a podcast where the following will be guaranteed:

  1. There won’t be 45 minutes of smalltalk at the beginning, instead we’ll dive right in.
  2. I won’t constantly interrupt the guest with inane questions. I’ll allow them to actually finish their stories.
  3. There will be minimal ads (because, like I said, I’ll have the resources). One can dream.
items.content_text:
One day when I actually have the time and resources (likely never, but one can still dream), I'm going to have a podcast where the following will be guaranteed: 

1) There won't be 45 minutes of smalltalk at the beginning, instead we'll dive right in. 
2) I won't constantly interrupt the guest with inane questions. I'll allow them to actually finish their stories.
3) There will be minimal ads (because, like I said, I'll have the resources). One can dream.

items.content_html: It’s mind blowing how a well thought out post with slight turns of phrase about reaching a birthday milestone obtains meh-levels of engagement, but paraphrasing (not even quoting!) a throw away line from a Chevy Chase movie garners nearly influencer levels of engagement. Never change, Threads.
items.content_text: It's mind blowing how a well thought out [post](https://alexanderbellgram.com/2024/12/09/here-we-are.html) with slight turns of phrase about reaching a birthday milestone obtains meh-levels of engagement, but paraphrasing (not even quoting!) a throw away line from a Chevy Chase movie garners nearly influencer levels of engagement. Never change, Threads.

items.content_html:
üéÇ üéÇ üéÇ Here we are: the big 5-oh. I asked ChatGPT to create a light but heartfelt post for me, but all I got out of that exercise was generic and saccharine outputs about how ‚Äú50 is the new 30‚Äù (news to me), and how I‚Äôm looking forward to new adventures‚Ä¶ blah blah blah. Plus, way too many birthday cake emojis.

Despite the milestone, it‚Äôs true that I‚Äôm feeling upbeat. I‚Äôm grateful for my beautiful family and life‚Äôs blessings. But the general tone of the ChatGPT responses - shockingly - reeked of AI. So I‚Äôm going to have to do this the hard way: write this post myself without the help of an AI assistant. Like an animal.

Let‚Äôs start with some perspective. Here‚Äôs some fun and interesting things that happened by the close of 1974:

  • Nixon resigned as US president.

  • Rubik‚Äôs Cube was invented.

  • The S&P 500 closed at 68.56.

  • The Dow closed at 616.24.

  • I was born.

There‚Äôs a funny line in ‚ÄúA Christmas Story‚Äù where Ralphie describes the feeling of time running out as ‚Äúthe Christmas noose beginning to tighten‚Äù. Turning 50 is kind of like that. My ‚Äútime-left-to-do-stuff" noose is beginning to tighten. Wait, that sounded darker than I intended. What I‚Äôm trying to say is that it‚Äôs a weird feeling knowing that I‚Äôm now older than my father was when I, as a kid, first realized he was OLD.

This being the age of electronic communication, I had a whole conversation with my extended family - over text - about how 50 is middle age (again, news to me). This is ridiculous given that the average lifespan in the US is around 80. The actuaries would say I‚Äôm well past middle-age. But I think the sentiment with my family was more complex than merely taking my expected lifespan and dividing it by two. Most of us, regardless of what the calendar says, feel like we‚Äôre perpetually in middle age. We‚Äôre constantly ‚Äúadulting‚Äù: managing family, job, our homes, hobbies, our health, and unexpected life events.

Some of these unexpected life events can permanently change your perspective on your life. My wife‚Äôs cancer journey really drove that point home for me: Life is short. Yeah, no kidding. My advice: don‚Äôt just sit on your ass too long. Thing‚Äôs aren‚Äôt as good or as bad as you think.

Bill Burr said it best: ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre gonna be fine. And even if you‚Äôre not, isn‚Äôt it better to exist thinking it‚Äôs going to be fine until it‚Äôs not? And then, you can handle it then. There‚Äôs no sense in ruining right now.‚Äù

Indeed. Enjoy right now. So, here‚Äôs to the next actuarially-adjusted 50 years.

Cheers and salud.

Plus, way too many birthday cake emojis.

Despite the milestone, it‚Äôs true that I‚Äôm feeling upbeat. I‚Äôm grateful for my beautiful family and life‚Äôs blessings. But the general tone of the ChatGPT responses - shockingly - reeked of AI. So I‚Äôm going to have to do this the hard way: write this post myself without the help of an AI assistant. Like an animal.

My ‚Äútime-left-to-do-stuff" noose is beginning to tighten. Wait, that sounded darker than I intended. What I‚Äôm trying to say is that it‚Äôs a weird feeling knowing that I‚Äôm now older than my father was when I, as a kid, first realized he was OLD.

This being the age of electronic communication, I had a whole conversation with my extended family - over text - about how 50 is middle age (again, news to me). This is ridiculous given that the average lifespan in the US is around 80. The actuaries would say I‚Äôm well past middle-age. But I think the sentiment with my family was more complex than merely taking my expected lifespan and dividing it by two. We‚Äôre constantly ‚Äúadulting‚Äù: managing family, job, our homes, hobbies, our health, and unexpected life events.

Some of these unexpected life events can permanently change your perspective on your life. My wife‚Äôs cancer journey really drove that point home for me: Life is short. Yeah, no kidding. My advice: don‚Äôt just sit on your ass too long. Thing‚Äôs aren‚Äôt as good or as bad as you think.

Bill Burr said it best: ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre gonna be fine. And even if you‚Äôre not, isn‚Äôt it better to exist thinking it‚Äôs going to be fine until it‚Äôs not? And then, you can handle it then. There‚Äôs no sense in ruining right now.‚Äù

Indeed. Enjoy right now. So, here‚Äôs to the next actuarially-adjusted 50 years. 

Cheers and salud.

items.content_html: Ever notice how Instagram will not allow your phone to go to sleep? Try it. Go the the main feed and then set your phone down. It won’t go to sleep. It will just keep playing whatever reel is on your screen on repeat forever until your phone battery is drained.

items.content_html: In The Godfather, Tom Hagan explains that Sollozzo is good with the knife. And yet, we never see Sollozzo use a knife. Ever. We never hear him bragging about how good he is with it. We never hear anyone else mention it either. Why the callout with the knife?

My family is totally normal.

items.content_html: The other day I did something I never thought I would end up doing: I called Amazon support. Apparently, one of my kids inadvertently signed up for an Amazon Music subscription (yes, those apparently exist). I called the number after trying to resolve the issue online and getting nowhere. My expectations were pretty much nonexistent. But I gotta say, after explaining the situation, Amazon support was extremely helpful and resolved the issue. Not only that, but I was refunded as well.

items.content_html:
A so-called financial columnist was recently scammed out of $50k in one of those “shoe-box” scams. There are entire YouTube channels dedicated to exposing this problem. The scam involves elaborate coordination across countries and continents. The complexity probably rivals that of some illegal drug organizations.

More here: www.goodmorningamerica.com/living/vi…

3 things I’d like to add to this:

  1. I am NOT a financial nor a security expert. I am a person on the internet who merely has a passing interest in both subjects.

  2. Please be very selective in who you take advice from, especially if they claim to be a “journalist expert‚Äù. This is not meant to criticize journalists in general. Some of these people do amazing work, sometimes risking their lives. And many are indeed experts in money and finance. But it appears that, at least in this space, there is not enough accountability.

  3. Please check on your family members who might not be very, er, “tech savvy”. Particularly elderly relatives. Elderly people in English-speaking countries are particularly easy targets for these types of scams.

Jake Kepins has a great summary over on Threads about the “expert journalist” as well. Worth the read. https://www.threads.net/@left_of_the_jokers/post/C3k2LGxruik

More here: [www.goodmorningamerica.com/living/vi...](https://www.goodmorningamerica.com/living/video/financial-columnist-speaks-after-losing-50k-scam-107359624)

3 things I'd like to add to this:

1) I am NOT a financial nor a security expert. I am a person on the internet who merely has a passing interest in both subjects.

2) Please be very selective in who you take advice from, especially if they claim to be a "journalist expert‚Äù. This is not meant to criticize journalists in general. Some of these people do amazing work, sometimes risking their lives. And many are indeed experts in money and finance. But it appears that, at least in this space, there is not enough accountability.

3) Please check on your family members who might not be very, er, "tech savvy". Particularly elderly relatives. Elderly people in English-speaking countries are particularly easy targets for these types of scams. 

Jake Kepins has a great summary over on Threads about the "expert journalist" as well. Worth the read.
https://www.threads.net/@left_of_the_jokers/post/C3k2LGxruik

items.content_html: Despite its name, the type system in Typescript is not exactly like the type system in C#. I understand this on a rational level. But not on a gut level. Sometimes hours are wasted because of this.
items.content_text: Despite its name, the type system in Typescript is not exactly like the type system in C#. I understand this on a rational level. But not on a gut level. Sometimes hours are wasted because of this.

items.title: Apple Music vs Spotify
items.content_html: The selection of music on Apple Music compared to Spotify continues to disappoint. I already pay for the service via iCloud+. I have heard others describe the sound quality as being superior. I WANT to like it and use it. But until I can import my HIGHLY CURATED playlists from Spotify to Apple Music without a significant fraction of tracks being dropped on the floor, I will continue to use (and pay extra for) Spotify.
items.content_text: The selection of music on Apple Music compared to Spotify continues to disappoint. I already pay for the service via iCloud+. I have heard others describe the sound quality as being superior. I WANT to like it and use it. But until I can import my HIGHLY CURATED playlists from Spotify to Apple Music without a significant fraction of tracks being dropped on the floor, I will continue to use (and pay extra for) Spotify.

items.content_html: Wanted to reshare this from @manton . This is so timely as I am going through the arduous process of integrating all my various socials. Challenging for sure. But interesting at the same time.
items.content_text:
Wanted to reshare this from [@manton](https://micro.blog/manton) . This is so timely as I am going through the arduous process of integrating all my various socials. Challenging for sure. But interesting at the same time.

Mastodon, Threads, Bluesky‚Ä¶ If you‚Äôre feeling overwhelmed by our post-Twitter social web, this post from Ben Werdmuller should hit home. My advice: don‚Äôt read everything. Post to your blog first, then dip into other apps whenever you have time. Never reload the never-ending algorithmic feeds.

Reader: werd.io

Manton Reece https://www.manton.org/2024/02/19/mastodon-threads-bluesky.html
